newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate ends up on cash demand for dlrs.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate ends up on cash demand for dlrs.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates closed up 20 basis points after rates came under modest upside pressure from investors selling paper to buy cheaply priced pesos, dealers said.
"The market looks under a little pressure and was partly due to the peso reaching a level which triggered demand for dollars," a fixed-income analyst said.
Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts meanwhile ended 0.2 of a centavo weaker at 7.8550/7.8590 per dollar, the first time they had closed softer in eight sessions, dealers said.
The analyst said a glut of paper from central bank intervention also exerted pressure on rates.
"The spread between bank and government rates has narrowed because the central bank has placed a hefty amount of paper," he said.
Banco de Mexico had placed a total of 23.5 billion pesos on the secondary market for the month to date in order to drain liquidity.
The central bank drained a total of 2.777 billion pesos on Monday by assigned three direct sales of paper and four repos.
Overnight rates on bank paper ended up 40 basis points at 19.85 percent, or just 45 basis points above government paper.
Liquidity of 740 million pesos was scheduled to return to the system on Tuesday from prior central bank participation.
